Description: Tyco International Ltd. agreed to pay a $50 million penalty to settle allegations that, from 1996 through 2002, it violated the federal securities laws by, among other things, utilizing various improper accounting practices and a scheme involving transactions with no economic substance to overstate its reported financial results by at least one billion dollars.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/news/press/2006/2006-58.htm

Description: A subsidiary of Tyco International Ltd. pleaded guilty to a criminal charge of conspiring to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and Tyco entered into a related non-prosecution agreement.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/opa/pr/subsidiary-tyco-international-ltd-pleads-guilty-sentenced-conspiracy-violate-foreign-corrupt

Description: York International settled allegations that its Delaware subsidiary paid approximately $522,500 to an intermediary while knowing that most of the money was intended to bribe United Arab Emirate officials; that its Dubai subsidiary authorized and made approximately $647,110 in kickback payments under the U.N. Oil for Food Program; and that various subsidiaries concealed kickback payments of over $7.5 million made to secure orders on certain commercial and government projects in the Middle East, India, China, Nigeria and Europe.
Info Source: https://www.sec.gov/litigation/litreleases/2007/lr20319.htm

Description: As part of its ongoing investigation into activity involving the United Nations Oil for Food program, the Justice Department agreed to defer the prosecution of York International Corporation. The agreement called for York to pay a $10 million penalty and have its compliance program and procedures reviewed by an independent monitor.
Info Source: https://www.justice.gov/archive/opa/pr/2007/October/07_crm_783.html
https://efoia.bis.doc.gov/index.php/documents/antiboycott/285-a715/file

Description: The settlement resolved allegations brought in a 2002 civil suit that New Jersey's pension fund portfolio suffered significant losses due to insider trading at Tyco, failure on the part of Tyco executives to disclose millions of dollars in personal loan benefits received from the company, accounting improprieties, and other fraud.
Info Source: http://www.nj.gov/oag/newsreleases08/pr20080430d.html

W. Grainger; and  White-Rodgers agreed to jointly pay a total of $625,000 in settlement of allegations the companies failed to meet requirements to collect out of service mercury-added thermostats required by the state Health and Safety Code.
